articles.headline: Overwatch Bets Gaming Fans Will Cheer for the Home Team to Save the World
articles.snippet: By branding its franchises to represent cities from Boston to Shanghai, a video game attracted investment from professional sports executives.
articles.abstract: By branding its franchises to represent cities from Boston to Shanghai, a video game attracted investment from professional sports executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jay Goldthwaite had never felt passion for a Boston sports team, no matter how often his neighbors’ cheers pierced the walls of his condo during playoff games for the Red Sox or the Celtics.
articles.byline: By Jason M. Bailey

articles.headline: Even in Better Times, Some Americans Seem Farther Behind. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: Two groups in particular — whites without a college degree, and black and Hispanic college graduates — have lagged as incomes and wealth have grown.
articles.abstract: Two groups in particular — whites without a college degree, and black and Hispanic college graduates — have lagged as incomes and wealth have grown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans’ household earnings are finally stretching back to their pre-recession heights. But feeling secure and comfortable isn’t only a measure of how much money you have. It’s also a measure of how much you have compared with others.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Florence Is Blamed for at Least Five Deaths as It Roars Ashore in North Carolina
articles.snippet: The storm made landfall near Wilmington, N.C., and had contributed to the deaths of at least five people. Hundreds more had to be rescued.
articles.abstract: The storm made landfall near Wilmington, N.C., and had contributed to the deaths of at least five people. Hundreds more had to be rescued.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, N.C. — After slamming into the Carolina coast on Friday with powerful winds and torrential rains, Hurricane Florence left a trail of devastation as it crawled over the southeastern part of the state, posing what may be its greatest threat in the days ahead as it roars inland with what are shaping up to be record-setting quantities of water.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Amy Harmon and David Zucchino

articles.headline: A Dallas Police Officer Shot Her Neighbor, and a City Is Full of Questions
articles.snippet: The shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer who entered his apartment has polarized Dallas and inflamed racial tensions.
articles.abstract: The shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer who entered his apartment has polarized Dallas and inflamed racial tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Botham Shem Jean analyzed risk for a living at a global auditing firm. For someone in his line of work, the evening was shaping up to be as risk-free as it gets: Alone, in his one-bedroom apartment one block from the Dallas Police Department headquarters.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Marina Trahan Martinez

articles.headline: Fraying Ties With Trump Put Jim Mattis’s Fate in Doubt
articles.snippet: Officials say that the president has soured on his defense secretary, and that Mr. Mattis is increasingly weary of capricious demands from his boss.
articles.abstract: Officials say that the president has soured on his defense secretary, and that Mr. Mattis is increasingly weary of capricious demands from his boss.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back when their relationship was fresh and new, and President Trump still called his defense secretary “Mad Dog” — a nickname Jim Mattis detests — the wiry retired Marine general often took a dinner break to eat burgers with his boss in the White House residence.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper

articles.headline: How a Ukrainian Hairdresser Became a Front for Paul Manafort
articles.snippet: To evade taxes, many shell companies are headed by “nominee directors” who can be homeless people or even victims of identity theft.
articles.abstract: To evade taxes, many shell companies are headed by “nominee directors” who can be homeless people or even victims of identity theft.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — At first glance, what happened to Yevgeny G. Kaseyev hardly seems like misfortune.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: The Economy Is Humming, but Trump Is Tweeting. Republicans Are Worried.
articles.snippet: The president and the healthy economy have become countervailing forces, with his self-inflicted wounds obscuring the Republican message, and buoying Democrats
articles.abstract: The president and the healthy economy have become countervailing forces, with his self-inflicted wounds obscuring the Republican message, and buoying Democrats
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Democrats enter the fall midterm campaign with palpable confidence about reclaiming the House and perhaps even the Senate, tensions are rising between the White House and congressional Republicans over who is to blame for political difficulties facing the party, with President Trump’s advisers pointing to the high number of G.O.P. retirements and lawmakers placing the blame squarely on the president’s divisive style.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Torrents of Water in Towns Across the Carolinas. And a Guy With a Boat.
articles.snippet: An improvised network of volunteers has sprung up to locate and rescue people who did not evacuate for Tropical Storm Florence.
articles.abstract: An improvised network of volunteers has sprung up to locate and rescue people who did not evacuate for Tropical Storm Florence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, N.C. — As the flat-bottomed fishing boat crept into a swirling river that had once been Summer Haven Lane, Tray Tillman scanned the brown floodwaters and half-submerged houses in search of somebody to save.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Typhoon Mangkhut Slams Hong Kong and Southern China
articles.snippet: The year’s most powerful storm, which left a deadly trail in the Philippines, scored a near-direct hit on Hong Kong and Macau before churning across China’s southern coast.
articles.abstract: The year’s most powerful storm, which left a deadly trail in the Philippines, scored a near-direct hit on Hong Kong and Macau before churning across China’s southern coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Typhoon Mangkhut battered Hong Kong and Macau on Sunday with 100 miles-per-hour wind gusts, drenching rains and 11-foot surges of seawater that inundated the first urban area of Asia to face the wrath of the year’s mightiest storm.
articles.byline: By Gerry Mullany, Tiffany May and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Storm ‘Has Never Been More Dangerous,’ Governor Warns
articles.snippet: Now a tropical depression, Florence has killed at least 16 people so far, and North Carolina officials expect the crisis to continue for many days.
articles.abstract: Now a tropical depression, Florence has killed at least 16 people so far, and North Carolina officials expect the crisis to continue for many days.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest updates on the storm, read our Monday live briefing here.
articles.byline: By David Zucchino, Alan Blinder and Jack Healy

articles.headline: In Michigan, Female Candidates Target a Key Trump Bloc: Union Voters
articles.snippet: While Hillary Clinton lost the state to Donald Trump, female Democratic candidates in Michigan are trying to create a new playbook, one union voter at a time.
articles.abstract: While Hillary Clinton lost the state to Donald Trump, female Democratic candidates in Michigan are trying to create a new playbook, one union voter at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROE, Mich. — It’s not the smokestacks that mark this part of southeast Michigan as a labor stronghold, or even the boxy union halls.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Walmart Finally Makes It to the Big Apple
articles.snippet: For years, the giant retailer faced political resistance in New York City, but now it has a foothold through its e-commerce site, Jet.com, which is starting a new push.
articles.abstract: For years, the giant retailer faced political resistance in New York City, but now it has a foothold through its e-commerce site, Jet.com, which is starting a new push.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a bank of the Bronx River, below the roar of the Bruckner Expressway, Walmart has finally found a foothold in a city that has long shunned it.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Kavanaugh’s Nomination in Turmoil as Accuser Says He Assaulted Her Decades Ago
articles.snippet: “I thought he might inadvertently kill me,” said Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused the Supreme Court nominee of sexual assault when they were teenagers. He has denied the allegations.
articles.abstract: “I thought he might inadvertently kill me,” said Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused the Supreme Court nominee of sexual assault when they were teenagers. He has denied the allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s bid to confirm Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court was thrown into uncertainty on Sunday as a woman came forward with explosive allegations that Mr. Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers more than three decades ago.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: One Face of Immigration in America Is a Family Tree Rooted in Asia
articles.snippet: More of the United States population is foreign-born now than at any time since 1910. Many immigrants came through family reunification policies that the Trump administration hopes to scale back.
articles.abstract: More of the United States population is foreign-born now than at any time since 1910. Many immigrants came through family reunification policies that the Trump administration hopes to scale back.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The young engineer arrived in America when he was 23 with a good education and little else. He landed a job at a nuclear test site, and built a home in Nevada. Between the 1970s and the mid-1980s, he brought his wife, mother, five sisters and a brother over from India, his native land.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: In the Carolinas, Churches Provide Spiritual Refuge and Shelter From the Storm
articles.snippet: Congregations across the storm-drenched region were at work on Sunday, even though many regular services were canceled.
articles.abstract: Congregations across the storm-drenched region were at work on Sunday, even though many regular services were canceled.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest updates on the storm, read our Monday live briefing here.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Richard Fausset and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: As Trump’s Trade War Mounts, China’s Wall Street Allies Lose Clout
articles.snippet: Beijing long turned to big banks to help get its way in Washington, but the old back channels have proven ineffective when it comes to trade tensions.
articles.abstract: Beijing long turned to big banks to help get its way in Washington, but the old back channels have proven ineffective when it comes to trade tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When President Bill Clinton deliberated whether he should loosen trade barriers against China, Wall Street helped plead Beijing’s case.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Kate Kelly and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Time Magazine Is Bought by Marc Benioff, Salesforce Billionaire
articles.snippet: The storied weekly spent less than a year as part of the Iowa-based Meredith Corporation. Its new owners, Mr. Benioff and his wife, are buying it for $190 million.
articles.abstract: The storied weekly spent less than a year as part of the Iowa-based Meredith Corporation. Its new owners, Mr. Benioff and his wife, are buying it for $190 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time, the pre-eminent weekly newsmagazine of the 20th century, will have new owners: Marc Benioff, the billionaire co-founder of the software company Salesforce, and his wife, Lynne.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and David Gelles

articles.headline: Betting Against Tesla: Short-Sellers Make Their Case
articles.snippet: Elon Musk says short-sellers are conspiring to bring his company down. Some seasoned investors say it’s just a matter of fundamentals.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk says short-sellers are conspiring to bring his company down. Some seasoned investors say it’s just a matter of fundamentals.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past year, Elon Musk has waged a bitter war of words with short-sellers, the investors who are betting billions of dollars that Tesla will fail.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Bloomberg May Run for President as a Democrat. Some of His Views May Cause Him Trouble.
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, acknowledged he has some differences with progressive Democrats, but said, “It’s impossible to conceive that I could run as a Republican.”
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York, acknowledged he has some differences with progressive Democrats, but said, “It’s impossible to conceive that I could run as a Republican.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Michael R. Bloomberg is actively considering a campaign for president as a Democrat in 2020, concluding that it would be his only path to the White House even as he voices stark disagreements with progressives on defining issues including bank regulation, stop-and-frisk police tactics and the #MeToo movement.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Trump Hits China With Tariffs on $200 Billion in Goods, Escalating Trade War
articles.snippet: The president said the tariffs, which will hit everyday consumer products, will go into effect on Sept. 24.
articles.abstract: The president said the tariffs, which will hit everyday consumer products, will go into effect on Sept. 24.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump, emboldened by America’s economic strength and China’s economic slowdown, escalated his trade war with Beijing on Monday, saying the United States would impose tariffs on $200 billion worth of goods and was prepared to tax all imports.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Hearing Set for Monday to Hear Kavanaugh and His Accuser
articles.snippet: Brett Kavanaugh, the Supreme Court nominee, said he is willing to talk to the Senate Judiciary Committee about accusations from a woman who said he sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers.
articles.abstract: Brett Kavanaugh, the Supreme Court nominee, said he is willing to talk to the Senate Judiciary Committee about accusations from a woman who said he sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, under mounting pressure from senators of his own party, will call President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, and the woman who has accused him of sexual assault before the committee on Monday for extraordinary public hearings only weeks before the midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Julie Hirschfeld Davis
